publicationstmt.publisher: State University of New York at Oswego

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid created with EADitor by Zachary Vickery.
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

did.abstract: The professional collection of James E. Perdue, the seventh President of SUNY Oswego and covers the years from 1963 to 1991. Dr. Perdue oversaw the ongoing physical transformation of the campus landscape and growth in its student and faculty ranks. He spearheaded the opening of the academic quad that includes Hewitt, Penfield Library and Lanigan, Mahar and Tyler Halls; several residence halls including what is known as “New Campus”; dining halls; the Culkin administration building and other spaces still of great use.

repository.corpname: State University of New York at Oswego

accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to the public.

bioghist.p: James Everett Perdue was the seventh president of S.U.N.Y. Oswego from 1965 until 1977. Under his presidency, S.U.N.Y. Oswego grew in many ways. Dorms, dining halls, Hewitt Union, Penfield Library, the administration building and various academic halls were built. Relations between the college, faculty and students were also improved during the period of student unrest in the early 1970's. Dr. Perdue left S.U.N.Y. Oswego in 1977 to become associate chancellor at S.U.N.Y. and was succeeded by Virginia Radley. Perdue retired in 1983 and spent the next several years involved in various academic projects around the country. In 1991, Dr. Perdue wrote his autobiography.
Dr. James E. Perdue died in 1998.

scopecontent.p: Included in the series is an autobiography, photographs, Perdue Inauguration papers, S.U.N.Y. Oswego 125th Anniversary papers, speeches, articles, pamphlets, college memorandum, reports, consultations, correspondence, and information on student unrest at Oswego during the 1970's.

userestrict.p: Please contact SUNY Oswego Archives and Special Collections for use restrictions.

scopecontent.p:
The autobiography of James E. Perdue, "The First Seventy-Five Years 1916-1991: An Autobiography", 375 pages, published in 1991. It details his thoughts on his family and life. Included is correspondence, newspaper clippings, photographs and genealogical information.
Sections:
In the Beginning The First Teaching Position Courtship 1938 The Wedding and After, 1939-1942 A New Home, A New Job, A New Baby The War Years, 1941-1945 Harvard and On, Late November 1943 New York City and Brooklyn Atlantic Sea Duty Home From The Wars The Deanship 1965 1966 1967 1968 1969 1970 1970 Afterthoughts 1971 1972 Europe August 1, 1972 -- Back At Work 1974 1975 1976 1977 1978 1979 1980 1981 1982 1983 1984 1985 1986 1987 1988 1989 1990 1991 Appendix: Perdue Family Heritage -- genealogy information, photographs, correspondence, newspaper clipping.
"The First Seventy-Five Years 1916-1991: An Autobiography". copy 2

Several photographs of Perdue in a group, by himself and also a picture taken by Perdue that was used as the cover photo for the S.U.N.Y. Oswego Student Directory 1973-74.
The photographss were taken in the 1960's and early 1970's. Others identified in some of the group photos are Janice Cromp, Gary Hoppee, Hilda Bohall, and Taylor Harter. There are 8 photographss total, one a duplicate.

Materials relating to the inauguration of James Perdue on May 14, 1966, as the 7th president of S.U.N.Y. Oswego. Included are:
Invitation to the inauguration. Bifold. 8 1/4" x 5 1/8"
Inauguration program. 10 1/4" x 7 1/4". 12 pp. Saturday, May 14, 1966 @ 11:00. Location: Mary V. Lee hall, Oswego, New York. 2 copies. Includes: Processional -- College Band, George J. Cuppernull, Director Presiding -- Charles Yager, Professor of Chemistry The National Anthem Invocation-- The Reverend Frederick R. Mills, Christ Church Anthem "Psalm 150"-- The Symphonic Choir, The College Orchestra, Maurice O. Boyd, Director Remarks-- Samuel B. Gould, President of the State University of New York Presentation of the President -- George M. Penney, Chairman, College Council Installation of the President -- Samuel B. Gould, President of the State University of New York Inaugural Address-- James E. Perdue, President of State University College, Oswego Benediction-- The Reverend Robert Hall, St. Mary's Church Recessional-- College Band. Includes lists of names -- Delegates from Learned Societies, Foundations and Professional Organizations Delegates from Colleges and Universities [inserted in program is supplemental list] Delegates from Colleges and Universities of The State University of New York.
Also includes Inaugural Committee members. Inserted in program are six cards [tickets?] measuring 5 1/4" x 2 1/4". The front of each card is printed "Inauguration '66, Spring Weekend". The reverse: Sunday, May 15th, Major Attraction, Louis Armstrong Concert, Lee Hall, 8:00 p.m. Saturday, May 14th, Inaugural Ball, Lakeside Dining Hall, 9:00 p.m. Friday, May 13th, Jam Session ("The Invictas"), Campus School Parking Lot, 10:00 p.m. Friday, May 13th, Symphonic Choir Spring Concert, Sheldon Auditorium, 8:00 p.m. Friday, May 13th, Phi Sig Beauty Contest, Sheldon Auditorium, 4:30 p.m. 2 copies.
6 copies of a booklet. 2 of the copies are in envelopes. Includes: Inaugural Convocation agenda Events of Inaugural Weekend Inaugual Remarks by Samuel B. Gould, President of the State Univeristy of New York. "The Analytic and the Synthetic" by James E. Perdue. 3-page transcript of speech.
Expression of gratitude card from Dr. James Everett Perdue "on the occasion of his installation as the Seventh President of State University of New York College at Oswego". 5 3/8" x 4 1/8"
36-page issue of "The Oswegonian". photocopy.

did.unittitle: State University of New York 25th Anniversary

scopecontent.p:
State University of New York 25th Anniversary
Various materials pertain to the anniversary celebration at Oswego and in Albany at S.U.N.Y.. The celebration at the Oswego campus was to commemorate the 25th year of SUNY campuses.
Included is correspondence, pamphlets, conference speakers, memorandum, financial records, speeches, S.U.N.Y. Albany Symposium materials, and conference planning papers.
The 25th Anniversary celebration took place at Oswego the weekend of October 8-11, 1973.

Articles, booklets and pamphlets were either written by Perdue or contain a speech or excerpt by him. There are five booklets written between 1965 and 1980.
The Oswegonian. January 15, 1965, article. "Dr. Perdue Named SUCO President".
1970 booklet, "Freedom and Responsibility on Campus" contains two chapters written by Dr.Perdue. Table of Contents: I. Freedom and Responsibility on Campus: An Overview II. The College Communinity: Present Tension and Future Shock III. The Oswego Strike: What Happened? IV. Communications Within the College V. The Changing Process of Education VI. Minority Groups VII. The College Community and Political Action.
A Presidential Farewell. Announcement and reservation form.
Included here is an 81-page booklet, "Proceedings First Annual Convocation of Distinguished Faculty" with a speech by Dr. Perdue. May 2, 1980. Includes: Memorandum from Chancellor Clifton R. Wharton regarding the Proceedings of Convocation of Distinguished Faculty. Includes supporting papers.
Opening Remarks by James E. Perdue, Vice Chancellor for Academic Programs, Policy and Planning.
Academic Climate and Potential of the State Univeristy of New York by Dorothy Rogers. 16 pp. Academic Climate and Potential of the State University of New York by Kingsley L. Greene. 19 p Academic Climate and Potential of the State University of New York by Henry L. Bretton. 10 pp. Academic Climate and Potential of the State University of New York by Dr. Warren H. Thomas.
State Unversity of New York Proposal for Honors Program. 6 pp. Remarks and Dialogue from Chancellor Clifton R. Wharton. 6 pp.
President's Convocation. September 12, 1967. Bifold. Dr. Perdue, SUNY Oswego President.
A Testimonial Luncheon and Reception in Honor of Dr. James E. Perdue. Trifold.

Various college memos regarding policies, meetings, news releases, budgets, benefits, reports and administration issues. The memos were written between 1966 and 1977, with the highest concentration being during the mid-1970's. There are about 200 memos contained in three folders.
Subjects include: Consortium Activity - Institutional Development Study Project. Speech by Samuel B. Gould - Mission and Purpose. Third Annual Faculty Assembly agenda and policies. Copy of "A Plan of Action" from Dr. Perdue. Promotions Procedures. Advisory Committee on the Selection of a Dean. Faculty salaries. Urban unrest. Campus student unrest. Proposed faculty bylaws. Registering students in programs prior to the time the programs have been approved. Movement for a moratorium on college activities. Equal Employment Opportunity. Term appointments for 1970-1971 academic year. Academic calendar changes. Wooden gavel made by Herbert S. Graves, class of 1930. Added to Dr. Sheldon's collection. Faculty library privileges. Local grievance procedures.

Memorandums to and from Dr. Perdue pertaining to policies, meetings, news releases, budgets and administration issues.
Subjects include: Report from Summer Conference Committee - "Freedom and Responsibility on Campus". Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation electrical line changes. Budget cuts.
City of Oswego / Niagara Mohawk construction projects resulted in loss of 500 campus parking spaces.
Faculty bylaws. State Dental Insurance Plan. Middle States Association and National Council for the Accreditation of Teacher Education. Oswego County United Fund Drive. New identification card for college community. Equal Employment Opportunity Policy Statement. Budget Bylaws Library staff and budget. Incident report. Hot line to Deputy to the Chancellor for major campus emergencies. State of New York Take Stock in America '72 Savings Bond Campaign. Travel expenses and use of automobiles policy statement. Microfilming machines usage. Microfilm Library Inventory. Safety Responsibilities. Anne Commerton appointed Acting Director of Libraries effective January 1, 1973. Recruitment Account Expenditures. First draft of local Master Plan submitted to Chancellor's Office. Annual reports. Reaction to State of College message. Call to faculty for upcoming faculty meeting - quorum needed. Vaccinia [Smallpox] Vaccination. Memo to all supervisors, re: summer responsibilities. Call to upcoming faculty meeting; new appointments listed. Seminar for Academic and Administrative Officers. 1973-1974 Campus Telephone Directory. Address by Professor Fred Hoyle. Personnel shifts. 1973-1974 faculty committee list. Criteria and procedures for Graduate Faculty membership. A Report on Energy Conservation Activities.

Incoming and outgoing memorandums - Dr. Perdue pertaining to administration issues, meetings, policies, budgets and reports.
Subjects include: Master Theses Energy / budget concerns Administrative Internship Program Equal Employment Opportunity Program Interviews for Executive Vice President and Provost positions. Annual Report formats.
Memo from Lynn Hemink to All Classified Service Personnel concerning civil service law and attendance rules.
Employee Tuition Waivers. New Faculty Orientation Sabbatical Leave. 1974-1975 College Directory. Personnel Responsibility Areas. Discretionary salary increases. 1974-1975 faculty committee list. American Council on Education Academic Administration Internship Program. Telephone tolls. Campus financial situation. Building temperatures Faculty Assembly bylaws. New York State Office of Employee Relations and CSEA negotiations impasse. Faculty and Staff Responsibilties in the Event of a Strike. Budget - 30% cut in telephone service. Travel expenses to SUNY-Wide Committees. Graduate Studies Dean vacancy. Temperature reduction in all campus buildings. Search for candidates for the position of Dean of Arts and Sciences.
State of the College Messages from 1967 to 1976. There are no reports contained here for 1972 and 1974. Each report is a summary of the framework, development and issues of the academic year.

Reports
"Report for October 1965" was submitted by Dr. Perdue to Samuel Gould, the President of S.U.N.Y. Albany. The report documents staff activities, curriculum, publications and research, student affairs. 8 pp.
New York State Education Department Evaluation Report of the college. January 1970. 22 pp.
"The College in Capsule - 1972-73" [3 pp] is an overview of the college regarding: New Academic Programs Student Health Services Student Government New Academic Appointments Oswego Overseas Hewitt Union Residence Hall Life Learning Resources Third Curriculum Community Service Center Facilities Programming
The "President's Annual Report to the Chancellor" for 1971-72. The report was written by Dr. Perdue. 6 pp. Includes: Student Affairs, Academic Affairs and General Administration.

Annual Report of the President
Annual Report of the President, 1972-1973. 21 pp. Includes: Academic Affairs Evaluation of Professional Faculty and Staff Student Enrollments Faculty Workload Role of Departmental Chairman Curricular Revision Center for the Improvement of Instruction Communication Administrative Reorganization Accountability Student Advisement Continuing Education Graduate Education Division of Arts and Sciences Division of Professional Studies Division of Graduate Studies Academic Support Services Administrative Affairs Student Affairs Graduate Admission Report, August 1972 - June 1973 Report on Proposals, July 1, 1972 - June 30, 1973 Schematic of Philosphy and Direction Division of Student Affairs Functional Organization chart.
Annual Report of the President, 1973 - 1974. 12 pp. Includes: Overview College Calendar Enrollment Accomplishments and Direction Administrative Affairs Personnel Computer Center Auxiliary Services Security Maintenance & Operations Business Affairs Student Affairs Curricular Innovations and Revisions Program Revisions New and Revised Academic Policies Administrative appointments Department chairperson designations or redesignations. Selected Problems and Recommended Actions.
Annual Report of the President, 1975 - 1976. 13 pp. Includes: Strategies for Survival Acadmic Affairs Curricular Innovations and Revisions Faculty Assembly actions Department chairperson designations or redesignations Academic Services Language Laboratory Learning Resources Center Penfield Library Personnel Office Student Financial Aids Veterans' Affairs Inservice Administrative Affairs Computer Center Campus Security Budget Office Maintenance Department Business Affairs Student Affairs Office of the President Equal Employment Opportunity College Development

Presidential Review Report 1969 - 1974 submitted by Dr. James E. Perdue, President, State University of New York College at Oswego. 30 pp. Includes: President's Statement of Self-Assessment, 1969-1974 Table of Contents: Prologue 1965-1969 Review 1969 - 1974, An Overview Time - Line Chart - following page 4 External Relationships Internal Relationships Institutions Tone Set by the President Administrative Leadership and Management Academic Leadership and Management Appendix -- A. Academic Programs Approved since 1969 B. Comparison of Projected Headcounts and FTE's to Actual Headcounts and FTE's C. Current projections through 1980 D. Total Faculty by numbers, ranks, degree preparation E. Comparative Budgets
A Presidential Purview of S.U.N.Y. Oswego: Challenges, Changes and Accomplishments, 1965 to 1978 by James E. Perdue. 39 pp.

Nature and Needs of Sponsored Research in Four-Year Colleges and Two-Year Agricultural and Technical Colleges of the State University of New York". 37 pp.
Handwritten note under title on title page, "Special project assigned to me by Chancellor 1981. JE Perdue." Contents: Introduction Improving Sponsored Research Faculty Criticisms From Two-Year Colleges Faculty Suggestions For Improvement From Two-Year Colleges Faculty Criticisms From Four-Year Colleges Faculty Suggestions For Improvement From Four-Year Colleges Conclusions and Recommendations Faculty Questionnaire

Consultancy
A report for a consultancy which Perdue participated in for Robert Finch, the Counsellor to the President of the United States.
The report is entitled "Selected Problems Facing Higher Education in the 1970's", dated November 2, 1970. 34 pp. The report was pieced together by 6 consultants total (including Dr. Perdue). Also included are 2 items of correspondence, 1 memorandum and a newpaper article regarding the project.

The next 10 folders contain various personal and professional correspondence ranging from 1963 to 1990. Correspondence is arranged chronologically. This first folder contains incoming and outgoing [although most correspondence is carbon copies of typed outgoing correspondence from Dr. Perdue] correspondence pertaining to his 1965 move from Colorado to Oswego, New York, including congratulations and acknowledgements.
The correspondence is in chronological order.

Correspondence from students, and correspondence pertaining to speaking engagements, etc. Incoming and outgoing. Typed and handwritten.
In chronological order. Also included is a typed quote by Dr. Richard Piez.
SUNY Oswego related correspondence. Incoming and outgoing. Typed, including carbon copies. In chronological order.

Correspondence pertains to early Oswego contact, trip expenses and SUNY Oswego information. Chronologically ordered.

Evaluation of the Chief Administrative Office, 1974, evaluates the Perdue administration at SUNY Oswego.
Includes memorandums from: Lynn D. Hemink Donald R. Mathieu, Chairman, Faculty Assembly
Correspondence from: James S. Smoot, Vice Chancellor for University-Wide Services and Special Programs, Albany, New York.
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Faculty Evaluation of Chief Administrative Officer invitation/directive. May 6, 1974.
Administrative Evaluation of President Perdue. May, 1974. 3 pp.
Evaluation of the President's Performance. (Minority Report by the Students). 11 pp.

Correspondence pertains to Dr. Perdue's move from Oswego to Albany, New York.
Correspondence between Dr. Perdue and Ernest L. Boyer.

Correspondence - Dr. George T. Land and others.
Handwritten note from JE Perdue, "Some of my correspondence with Dr. George T. Land - author, consultant and lecturer at universities and businesses such as General Motors. Geo and I did several things together at a number of colleges".
Correspondence is arranged chronologically. 1977 - 1981. Handwritten and typed.
Correspondents in addition to Dr. Land:
President Donald E. Walker, Southeastern Massachusetts University, North Dartmouth, Mass. Attached to correspondence is a 1977 seven-page article, "The Halitosis Strategy of Survival" by Donald E. Walker.
George Keller, SEARCH, A journal of scholarly research.
Dr. Gabriele L. Rico, School of Humanities + the Arts, San Jose State University, San Jose, CA Attached is a five-page "studen evalution of clustering."
Clifton R. Wharton, Jr., Chancellor, SUNY, Albany, New York.

Incoming and outgoing, handwritten and typed, correspondece between Robert Greenleaf and Dr. Perdue. A note from JEP, "Letters to Robt Greenleaf, author. comments on his ideas + Mss."
Additional correspondents include: Hugh G. Lally, Promotion Director, Paulist Press Ralph L. Spencer, Acting Provost, SUNY Oswego
Constantine B. Simonides, Coference Convener, Center for Applied Studies, Conference on Undergraduate Leadership Potential, Nashville, Indiana.
Rev. Oliver F. Williams, C.S.C., University of Notre Dame.
Larry Spears, Executive Director, The Robert K. Greenleaf Center.
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - "Is It More Blessed To Give Than To Receive?" by Robert K. Greenleaf. Excerpt from Friends Journal, Quaker Thought and Life Today. May 1, 1976. photocopy. 2 pp.
Commencement talk by Michael Greenleaf [handwritten note - "18 year old grandson"], Solebury School, New Hope, Pa. June 5, 1976. 3 typed pages.
"Robert Greenleaf: The gentle taskmaster of servant leaders". 2 pp. Not cited. n.d.

Personal correspondence pertain to Dr. Perdue's move to Albany, New York, from Oswego. Incoming and outgoing correspondence. Handwritten and typed.
Correspondents include:

Bruce Dearing, University Professor of Humanitites in Medicine, SUNY Upstate Medical. Lynn D. Hemink, SUNY Oswego Susan Fratkin, National Association of State Universities and Land-Grant Colleges. A Response to the 70's. State University College at Oswego's Reply to the 1972 Master Plan of State University of New York. First Draft. March, 1973. James E. Perdue, President. 94 pp.
Table of Contents:
Introduction I. The Region, The State, and Admissions Regionalism Admissions programs Freshman class profile Transfer students Gifted high school students II. The Academic Programs General studies Energy studies Communications programs Programs of interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary nature "Classical College" Teacher Education Continuing education of teachers Technical studies Career studies Health science Practicum Honors programs International education Graduate programs Interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary programs Lifelong learning III. Faculty and Staff Consultation on programs existing and proposed Equal opportunity employment procedures Excellence in teaching Non-teaching professionals Student affairs Research IV. The Student and Campus Life Time-shortened degrees Deferred admissions and "step-out" programs External degrees Off-campus programs Practicum and internships Intercultural understanding Retirees and senior citizens Student rights Library Campus School Alumni, community and public affairs V. The Seventies

"Morsels for Meditation, Gleanings Over the Years" by James E. Perdue. 76 pages.
A second copy was added. It includes additional pages and expanded sections. The book includes passages / quotes from books and magazines collected over the years by Dr. Perdue. They have been arranged into ten catagories: Administration Deans & Presidents Leadership Learning Liberal Education Morality--Honor--Ethics Power Religion Teaching Communication -- Writing
In addition is inserted [not attached to original spiral binding] is "The Career Development Quiz". 6 pp.
1969 two-page statement concerning pilot program. (3 copies)

Correspondence, memorandums and statements concerning a request from Dr. Perdue to department chairs and administrative officers. Dr. Perdue asks that two statements be submitted concerning outstanding characteristics and limitations and a second statement concerning administrative philosophy and role.
Included are responses from George F. Lambert, Dean of Men; R. W. Rock; the Dean of Women; the Dean of Students; the Division of Student Personnel. A one-page typed meeting agenda, May 27, 1966 is included.

35 typed memorandums and correspondence with attachments that include justification for position reports. Correspondence is between James E. Perdue and State University of New York administration.
Correspondents include: Dr. Ernest L. Boyer Dr. James A. Frost Dr. Harold Delaney Thomas J. Peterson Dr. Harold Delaney Harvey Randall

5 audiotapes contain speeches by Dr. Perdue. Dates range from 1959 to 1974.
All audiotapes are TDK Professional Master Series. IECI/TYpe1 Normal Position. Acoustic Master. AM 60 Identifying handwritten labels on each:
Pres. Perdue / Freshman Assembly / 9/19/59. Pres. Perdue / Stillwater / July 31, 1961. Pres. Perdue / 9/17/63 / A+S Faculty. Pres. Perdue Inauguration 1966. SUNY Oswego President Perdue. 8/29/74.

Speeches and related materials were either written or given by James Perdue. The speeches were given between the years 1965 and 1969. Speeches include messages to the faculty, addressing issues and concerns or were given at special events such as commencements, dinners or conferences. The length of the speeches range up to 29 pages. There are several speeches with the notes attached. Five speeches are also available here on audiotape. These range from 1959-1974 and are addressed to faculty, Inauguration speeches or Assembly speeches.
The Post-Modern Mind. Commencement Address. University of Denver. June 11, 1965. Graduate Education: Fact or Fiction. Graduate Luncheon. July 28, 1965. 2 copies. A Communicty of Scholars. General Faculty meeting. September 9, 1965. 2 copies. The Analytic and the Synthetic. Inaugural Address of Dr. Perdue. May 14, 1966.
President's Convocation for Freshmen. September 11, 1966. 29 pp. 5 1/2" x 8 1/2" typed pp. Summer Session Conference. Miami. November 1967. 8 typed pages with editing notes.
Statement for disruptive activities. 1968. 3 carbon copies. Today in the First Day of the Rest of Your Life. For Special Issue of Oswegonian. President's Message. May 28, 1969. 2 typed pages, carbon copy.

Speeches are arranged chronologically. This folder is a continuation of folder 02-01.
Speeches include:
Members of the Graduating Class of 1970. 3 typed pages. The College Community. 2 typed pages. August 5, 1970. September 1970. President's message. 2 pp. carbon copy. The Community and the College: A Challenge for the Seventies. Draft. September 1970.
Greetings to Class of 1971 from Dr. Perdue. President's Speech. October 6, 1972. 16 typed pages with editing notes. Draft of President's message. 1 typed page. n.d. Handwritten "speech to new students. 1/12/75"
Liberal Education: What Is It? Remarks to the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York, February 25, 1975. J.E. Perdue. 25 typed pages. Award of Merit Dinner speech. May 1975. 4 typed pages. 4 handwritten pages. Speech to the Faculty. Dr. James E. Perdue. September 4, 1975. 3 typed pages. 3 copies
American Association of State Colleges and Universities Proceedings, 1975. Article by Dr. Perdue on pps. 15-24. "President to Presidents Lecture." Complete 83-page journal.
President-to-Presidents Lecture. 15th Annual Meeting of American Association of State Colleges and Universities. November 12, 1975. 11 typed pages. 2 copies.

Speeches
1975 Speech to the Faculty, 3 pp. 1976 speech, "A Framework for Change", 6 pp. 2 copies
Draft of Oswegonian editorial by President Perdue. June 1976
Speech to New Faculty. August 30, 1976. Handwritten speech to General Faculty. September 13, 1976
Small folder of speeches, some edited copies on a variety of subjects. 1976
43-page speech on the nature/function of colleges and universities. No title, date or further citing.

Five photographs mounted for a display.
Group photograph - Dr. Perdue, center; Virginia L. Radley, right. Unidentified gentleman on the left.
Dr. Perdue on a bicycle
Dr. Perdue with six individuals [students?] and bicycle.
Dr. Perdue with large group of students on campus near Hewitt Union.

1970's- Student Unrest
Various materials such as newspaper articles, magazine articles and miscellaneous memos, newsletters, position papers and pamphlets that approach the problems of and reasons behind the student unrest are included in box 3.
Five reports by The University of Denver including - "The Workshop on Liberal Arts Education" 7 pp, 1964 April 1969 "Discipline Code for the University of Denver" 30 pp April 1969 "Code of Procedures for all Agencies" 11 pp 1969 memorandum from Chancellor Maurice B. Mitchell concerning the attached "Declaration of Student Demands" 14 pp 1969 "Principles of Student Life at the University of Denver". 2 pp
June 1969 article from "Higher Education and National Affairs" publication, "Consensus on Handling Campus Disorders Urged by National Commission". 7 pp
Congressional Record, 91st Congress, "Congress Looks at the Campus: The Brock Report on Student Unrest". 7 pp
"Mid-Elders To The Rescue" by Stan Haring, WE:HE/ME System for human relations founder. 2 pp
20-page publication of the EFL College Newsletter, 1970. "Guidelines on University Organization" published by the Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada. 17 pp
"Campus Disorders 'Are You Ready For This?'" by the Association of Physical Plant Administrators, April 1970. 6 pp
"Just Law & Civil Order" pamphlet, Christopher News Notes, May 1970.
May 1970 letter from Robert F. Goheen, Princeton University, to Princeton Alumni, Parents and Friends. 3 pp
"Overcommunication or A Forgotten Right: The Right to Affirm", address by Daniel J. Boorstin, June 7, 1970. 12-page pamphlet
University of Buffalo memorandum from Thomas T. Frantz, Secretary pro tem, June 1970.
Press release from Harvard University, June 1970 from the office of the Vice Chancellor concerning the election and class schedules. 2 pp. Attached is a 1-page description of Cornell University's Fall Semester Plans.
6-page position paper "in opposition to the 'Princeton Plan' for a political-activity recess in colleges and universities in the Fall of 1970." by Keith Spalding, President, Franklin and Marshall College, June 1970.
Two 1970 letters of correspondence between Logan Wilson, President of the American Council on Education and Randolph W. Thrower, Commissioner, Internal Revenue Service. Attached is June, 1970, 4-page "Guidelines on Questions Relating to Tax Exemption and Political Activities Statement of the American Council on Education".
Higher Education and National Affairs publication, June, 1970, "ACE Issues Guidelines About College Political Activity. Tax Exemption". 12 pp.
3-page report by the Board of Trustees of the California State Colleges, "Committee on Faculty and Staff Affairs" concerning salary increases July, 1970.
University of Denver newsletter excerpt, "Excerpts From a Letter to a Concerned Parent." 1 page.
"Students Assess Their Colleges and Universities: Historical Backgrounds" by Donald T. Williams, Jr., University of Washington. 10 pp. with 2 page bibliography.

Eleven photographs are identified in detail in Photo record 2001.015.0002. a. - x.
Also includes: Three photographs used in a display. Individuals identified: The Perdue Family Eleanor Filburn Gus Silveira

Journal Articles and Reports
Articles include" "Education in Utopia" by Bruce Dearing, from "Alumni Review", Lebanon Valley College, 1964. 4 pp.
"Education and Research" from Ford Foundation Annual Report, 1968. 1 page.
"The University and Student Dissent" by Robert S. Morison, from "Science", March 1969. 1 page
2-page excerpt from U. S. News and World Report, July, 1969, "Needed Immediately: 200 College Presidents".
"The Hampton Institute Strike of 1927, A Case Study in Student Protest" by Edward K. Graham, reprint from "The American Scholar" 15 pp. Includes "Postscript: The 1969 Demonstrations" by Margaret Mead.
"The New Left and the Old Law" by William A. Stanmeyer, reprinted from the "American Bar Association Journal", April 1969. 5 pp.
"Co-Ed Living" by Betty Rollin from "Look" magazine, 1969. 6 pp.
"Danger: proceed at the risk of rationality" by Robert J. Schaefer. "Relevance or Revolt" by Edmund W. Gordon. Both from "Perspectives on Education", 1969. 16 pp
"Where is all began - Berkeley, 5 Years Later, Is Radicalized, Reaganized, Mesmerized" by A. H. Raskin from The New York Times Magazine, 1970. 18 pp.
"Dr. Pitzer Looks at the '70's" from Alumni Almanac, 1970. 1 page.
"The Spirit of '70, Six Historians Reflect on What Ails the American Spirit" from Newsweek, July, 1970. 16-page excerpt including the following articles: "The Age of Rubbish" by Richard Hofstadter. "We Will Meet As Enemies" by Andrew Hacker. "A Massive Breakdown" by Eugene D. Genovese. "A Case of Hypochondria" by Daniel J. Boorstin. "Again - Don't Tread on Me" by Staughton Lynd. "The Velocity of History" by Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr.
Time magazine excerpt, October, 1970 - "Investigation, Kent State: Another View". 1 page.
Time magazine, November, 1970 - "Man in the Middle" 1 page.
Colorado College magazine excerpt, 1970. 16 pp. Included: "A New Kind of Calendar for a Block Course Plan".
"The Colorado College Plan: An Academic Program Changes, But a Commitment Does Not" by Barbara M. Arnest.
"'Scientia et Disciplina'': The Motto as Background for the New Course Plan" from a memorandum by Glenn E. Brooks.
"To Decide, Introspection, discussion, and lesser decisions, then faculty endorsement of an academic change."
"The Student In An Age of Unrest" by N. Edd Miller, President, University of Nevada. 4 page excerpt from "New York State Bar Journal", February, 1971.
"The Squaring of America" 4 page interview with Herman Kahn.
"The Recovery of Civility, Notes for the Long Trek Back" by Ferdinand Mount. Reprint of July 1973 "Encounter". 8 pp.
"New Threats to Academic Freedom" by John H. Bunzel. 4 pp.
Higher Education and National Affairs excerpt, Vol. XVIII, No. 24. "Nine Presidents List 'Practical Lessons' Of Campus Disruption". 2 pp.

"How to Prevent the Destruction of the University", address by Leland C. Marsh, May 1970.

New York Times article, 1970, "Brewster Explains Campus Unrest" by Peter Kihss.
Palladium TImes article, September, 1972, "Need Some New Values, He Says".
Los Angeles Times article by Robert J. Dolan, "Social Struggle in U.S. Pits Middle Class Against Upper Middle Class, Says Author."
National Observer article, July, 1973, "Sifting Revolution's Ashes for Salvage" by Fred Hechinger.
New York Times, April, 1974, "The Mood on Campus" by Leslie Epstein.
"Winds of change hit academic world" by Dr. Benjamin Fine.
"Student Trustees a Small Minority" by William K. Stevens.

"Combat on the Campus" by Dr. Max Rafferty.
"Regents Asked to Keep Angela Davis".
"U.C. Prof. Raps Angela Ouster".

"Youth's Faith . . ."
"Hitch Warns U.C. Faculty To Change" by Larry Spears.

"U.C. Grads Like New Rites" by Larry Spears, Oakland Tribune, June, 1970.

Framed portrait of Dr. James Perdue. Gold frame 21" x 17". Linen matt with gold trim. Linen is soiled. Black & white photograph. 14" x 10.5" View of campus behind Dr. Perdue.
The framed portrait was transferred to the college archives from University Development after being removed from Sheldon Hall.
